name: amphenidone
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1373

name: amphenidone
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1373
Reason: Amphenidone is a compound composed of two aromatic rings connected by a nitrogen atom and one of the rings has an additional keto group. The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. Each additional aromatic ring typically raises the melting point due to increased pi-stacking interactions and molecular symmetry, contributing an estimated increase of about +40 degrees Celsius. The nitrogen atom present in the amide-like group (-NH-) can form hydrogen bonds, which generally increases the melting point further; this effect can add approximately +20 degrees Celsius. The keto group (-C=O) can also participate in hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, potentially increasing the melting point. The contribution of the keto group is estimated to be about +30 degrees Celsius. This leads us to the prediction.
Prediction: 5.5 (base benzene) + 40 (additional aromatic ring) + 20 (amide-like NH group) + 30 (keto group) = 95.5 degrees Celsius

name: amphenidone
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1373
Reason: Amphenidone is composed of a biphenyl structure, two aromatic rings connected by a nitrogen atom, and one ring is substituted with a keto group. The basic unit of benzene has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The presence of a second aromatic ring can increase molecular symmetry and potential pi-pi stacking interactions, which typically adds an increase in melting point, estimated at approximately +80 degrees Celsius for the substantial structural contribution. The nitrogen atom bridging the rings can introduce additional intermolecular forces like hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, contributing approximately +40 degrees Celsius. The keto group also introduces additional dipole-dipole interactions and potential for hydrogen bonding, which is estimated to raise the melting point by around +35 degrees Celsius. Combining these effects gives us the predicted melting point value.
Prediction: 5.5 (base, benzene) + 80 (second aromatic ring) + 40 (nitrogen atom bridging rings) + 35 (keto group) = 160.5 degrees Celsius

name: amphenidone
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1373
Reason: Considering the molecular structure of amphenidone (Nc1cccc(c1)n2ccccc2=O), we will examine effects of the functional groups on the benzene base unit. The base benzene molecule has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The following functional groups will affect the melting point: -NH group, primary amino, typical +40 to +50 due to hydrogen bonding and increased polarity. -NO group on the opposite ring, typical +50 to +60 due to the strong intermolecular forces, including hydrogen bonding and the polar nature of the nitro group. Two benzene rings: +25 to +35 each due to increased molecular weight and pi-pi stacking interactions. The ketone (=O) group: +20 to +30 due to dipole-dipole interactions and possible hydrogen bonding with the NH group on the other ring. Each of these effects is additive, so we sum the contributions of all groups to predict the melting point. The specific increments were chosen based on typical values observed for similar molecular fragments.
Prediction: The predicted melting point of amphenidone is 5.5 (base benzene) + 40 (NH group) + 50 (NO group) + 60 (2x benzene rings) + 25 (ketone group) = 180.5 °C
